column2: DISEASES OF CATS.
column3: DISEASES OF CATS.

column2: Through the kindness of friends I am enabled to give recipes for medicines considered as useful, or, at any rate, tending to abate the severity of the attack in the one, and utterly eradicate the other.
column3: Through the kindness of friends I am enabled to give recipes for medicines considered as useful, or, at any rate, tending to abate the severity of the attack in the one, and utterly eradicate the other.

column2: Care should always be taken on the first symptoms of illness to remove the animal at once from contact with others.
column3: Care should always be taken on the first symptoms of illness to remove the animal at once from contact with others.

column2: CATARRHAL FEVERS.
column3: CATARRHAL FEVERS.

column2: From A.D. 1414 up to 1832 no fewer than nineteen widespread outbreaks of this kind have been recorded.
column3: From a d fourteen fourteen up to eighteen thirty two no fewer than nineteen widespread outbreaks of this kind have been recorded.

column2: The most notable of these was in 1796, when the cats in England and Holland were generally attacked by the disease, and in the following year when it had spread over Europe and extended to America; in 1803, it again appeared in this country and over a large part of the European continent.
column3: The most notable of these was in seventeen ninety six, when the cats in England and Holland were generally attacked by the disease, and in the following year when it had spread over Europe and extended to America; in eighteen o three, it again appeared in this country and over a large part of the European continent.

column2: The symptoms are intense fever, prostration, vomiting, diarrhoea, sneezing, cough, and profuse discharge from the nose and eyes.	The symptoms are intense fever, prostration, vomiting, diarrhoea, sneezing, cough, and profuse discharge from the nose and eyes.
Sometimes the parotid glands are swollen, as in human mumps.
column3: Sometimes the parotid glands are swollen, as in human mumps.

column2: The treatment consists in careful nursing and cleanliness, keeping the animal moderately warm and comfortable.	The treatment consists in careful nursing and cleanliness, keeping the animal moderately warm and comfortable.

The disease rapidly produces intense debility, and therefore the strength should be maintained from the very commencement by frequent small doses of strong beef-tea, into which one grain of quinine has been introduced twice a day, a small quantity of port wine (from half to one teaspoonful) according to the size of the cat, and the state of debility.
column3: The disease rapidly produces intense debility, and therefore the strength should be maintained from the very commencement by frequent small doses of strong beef tea, into which one grain of quinine has been introduced twice a day, a small quantity of port wine (from half to one teaspoonful) according to the size of the cat, and the state of debility.

column2: If there is no diarrhoea, but constipation, a small dose of castor oil or syrup of buckthorn should be given.
column3: If there is no diarrhoea, but constipation, a small dose of castor oil or syrup of buckthorn should be given.

column2: Solid food should not be allowed until convalescence has set in.
column3: Solid food should not be allowed until convalescence has set in.

column2: Isolation, with regard to other cats, and disinfection, should be attended to.
column3: Isolation, with regard to other cats, and disinfection, should be attended to.

column2: Simple Catarrh demands similar treatment.	Simple Catarrh demands similar treatment.
Warmth, cleanliness, broth, and beef-tea, are the chief items of treatment, with a dose of castor oil if constipation is present.
column3: Warmth, cleanliness, broth, and beef tea, are the chief items of treatment, with a dose of castor oil if constipation is present.

column2: Probably inoculation with cultivated or modified virus would be found a good and safe preventative."
column3: Probably inoculation with cultivated or modified virus would be found a good and safe preventative."

column2: I was anxious to know about this, as inoculation used to be the practice with packs of hounds.
column3: I was anxious to know about this, as inoculation used to be the practice with packs of hounds.

column2: It will be observed that Dr. Fleming treats the distemper as a kind of influenza, and considers one of the most important things is to keep up the strength of the suffering animal.
column3: It will be observed that dr Fleming treats the distemper as a kind of influenza, and considers one of the most important things is to keep up the strength of the suffering animal.

column2: Other members of the R.C.V.S., whom I have consulted, have all given the same kind of advice, not only prescribing for the sick animal wine, but brandy, as a last resource, to arouse sinking vitality.
column3: Other members of the r c v s, whom I have consulted, have all given the same kind of advice, not only prescribing for the sick animal wine, but brandy, as a last resource, to arouse sinking vitality.

column2: Mr. George Cheverton, of High Street, Tunbridge Wells, who is very successful with animals and their diseases, thinks it best to treat them homoeopathically.
column3: mr George Cheverton, of High Street, Tunbridge Wells, who is very successful with animals and their diseases, thinks it best to treat them homoeopathically.

column2: The following is what he prescribes as efficacious for some of the most dire complaints with which cats are apt to be afflicted.
column3: The following is what he prescribes as efficacious for some of the most dire complaints with which cats are apt to be afflicted.

column2: WORMS.
column3: WORMS.

column2: For a full-grown cat give 3 grains of santonine every night for a week or 10 days; it might be administered in milk, or given in a small piece of beef or meat of any kind.
column3: For a full grown cat give three grains of santonine every night for a week or ten days; it might be administered in milk, or given in a small piece of beef or meat of any kind.

column2: After the course give an aperient powder.
column3: After the course give an aperient powder.

column2: MANGE.
column3: MANGE.

column2: A most useful lotion is acid sulphurous, 1 oz. to 5 oz. of water, adding about a teaspoonful of glycerine, and sponging the affected parts twice or thrice daily.
column3: A most useful lotion is acid sulphurous, one ounce. to five ounces. of water, adding about a teaspoonful of glycerine, and sponging the affected parts twice or thrice daily.

column2: COLDS.
column3: COLDS.

column2: The symptoms are twofold, usually there is constant sneezing and discharge from the nose.
column3: The symptoms are twofold, usually there is constant sneezing and discharge from the nose.

column2: COUGHS.
column3: COUGHS.

column2: DISTEMPER.
column3: DISTEMPER.

column2: Early symptoms should be noted and receive prompt attention; this will often cut short the duration of the malady.
column3: Early symptoms should be noted and receive prompt attention; this will often cut short the duration of the malady.

column2: The first indications usually are a disinclination to rest in the usual place, seeking a dark corner beneath a sofa, etc.
column3: The first indications usually are a disinclination to rest in the usual place, seeking a dark corner beneath a sofa, etc

column2: The eyes flow freely, the nose after becoming hard and dry becomes stopped with fluid, the tongue parched, and total aversion to food follows.
column3: The eyes flow freely, the nose after becoming hard and dry becomes stopped with fluid, the tongue parched, and total aversion to food follows.

column2: When the nose becomes dry, and the eye restless and glaring, give belladonna.
column3: When the nose becomes dry, and the eye restless and glaring, give belladonna.

column2: CANKER OF EAR.
column3: CANKER OF EAR.

column2: When internal, drop into the affected ear, night and morning, 3 or 5 drops of the following mixture:
column3: When internal, drop into the affected ear, night and morning, three or five drops of the following mixture:

column2: APERIENT.
column3: APERIENT.

column2: Get a chemist to rub down a medium-size croton bean with about 40 grains of sugar of milk, and divide into four powders.
column3: Get a chemist to rub down a medium size croton bean with about forty grains of sugar of milk, and divide into four powders.

column2: Large cats often require two powders. The dose might be repeated if necessary.
column3: Large cats often require two powders. The dose might be repeated if necessary.

column2: REMEDIES AND STRENGTHENING MEDICINES.
column3: REMEDIES AND STRENGTHENING MEDICINES.

column2: Santonine.
column3: Santonine.

column2: Mr. Frank Upjohn, of Castelnau, Barnes, has also kindly forwarded me his treatment of some few of the cat ailments.
column3: mr Frank Upjohn, of Castelnau, Barnes, has also kindly forwarded me his treatment of some few of the cat ailments.

column2: Mindful of the old proverb that "In a multitude of counsellors there is wisdom," I place all before my friends, and those of the cat, that they may select which remedy they deem best:
column3: Mindful of the old proverb that "In a multitude of counsellors there is wisdom," I place all before my friends, and those of the cat, that they may select which remedy they deem best:

column2: DISTEMPER.
column3: DISTEMPER.

column2: Mix for ointment.
column3: Mix for ointment.

column2: Then give sulphide of mercury, 3 grains, two or three times on alternate nights.
column3: Then give sulphide of mercury, three grains, two or three times on alternate nights.

column2: PURGATIVE.
column3: PURGATIVE.

column2: Nothing like castor oil for purgation; half the quantity of syrup of buckthorn, if necessary, may be added.
column3: Nothing like castor oil for purgation; half the quantity of syrup of buckthorn, if necessary, may be added.

column2: WORMS.
column3: WORMS.

column2: Two or three grains of santonine in a teaspoonful of castor oil, for two or three days.
column3: Two or three grains of santonine in a teaspoonful of castor oil, for two or three days.

column2: CATARRH.
column3: CATARRH.

column2: Mix. Give 1 teaspoonful every two or three hours.
column3: Mix. Give one teaspoonful every two or three hours.

column2: FLEAS, AND IRRITATION OF SKIN.
column3: FLEAS, AND IRRITATION OF SKIN.

column2: EYE OINTMENT.
column3: EYE OINTMENT.

column2: Red oxide of mercury, 12 grains; spermaceti ointment, 1 oz.
column3: Red oxide of mercury, twelve grains; spermaceti ointment, one ounce.

column2: Mix.
column3: Mix.

column2: The above prescription was given to me many years ago by the late Dr. Walsh (Stonehenge), and I have found it of great service, both for my own eyes, also those of animals and birds.
column3: The above prescription was given to me many years ago by the late dr Walsh (Stonehenge), and I have found it of great service, both for my own eyes, also those of animals and birds.

column2: Wash the eyes carefully with warm water, dry off with a soft silk handkerchief, and apply a little of the ointment.
column3: Wash the eyes carefully with warm water, dry off with a soft silk handkerchief, and apply a little of the ointment.

column2: Dr. Walsh informed me that he deemed it excellent for canker in the ear, but of that I have had no experience.
column3: dr Walsh informed me that he deemed it excellent for canker in the ear, but of that I have had no experience.

column2: FOR MANGE.
column3: FOR MANGE.

column2: Another remedy: give a teaspoonful of castor oil; next day give raw meat, dusted over with flowers of sulphur.
column3: Another remedy: give a teaspoonful of castor oil; next day give raw meat, dusted over with flowers of sulphur.

column2: Of all the ailments, both of dogs and cats, distemper is the worst to combat, and is so virulent and contagious that I have thought it well to offer remedies that are at least worthy of a trial, though when the complaint has firm hold, and the attack very severe, the case is generally almost hopeless, especially with high-bred animals.
column3: Of all the ailments, both of dogs and cats, distemper is the worst to combat, and is so virulent and contagious that I have thought it well to offer remedies that are at least worthy of a trial, though when the complaint has firm hold, and the attack very severe, the case is generally almost hopeless, especially with high bred animals.

column2: POISON.
column3: POISON.

column2: It is not generally known that the much-admired laburnum contains a strong poison, and is therefore an exceedingly dangerous plant.
column3: It is not generally known that the much admired laburnum contains a strong poison, and is therefore an exceedingly dangerous plant.

column2: A small dose of juice infused under the skin is quite sufficient to kill a cat or a dog.
column3: A small dose of juice infused under the skin is quite sufficient to kill a cat or a dog.

column2: Children have died from eating the seeds, of which ten or twelve were sufficient to cause death.
column3: Children have died from eating the seeds, of which ten or twelve were sufficient to cause death.

column2: How many cases have happened before the danger was discovered is of course only a matter of conjecture, as few would suspect the cause to come from the lovely plant that so delights the eye.
column3: How many cases have happened before the danger was discovered is of course only a matter of conjecture, as few would suspect the cause to come from the lovely plant that so delights the eye.
